lead_paragraph: On the morning of April 24, Emily Arnold and Youssef Ait-Khouya walked over the dunes at Coral Pink Sand Dunes State Park outside Kanab, Utah, chose a spot to get married and began accessorizing it. They laid down Moroccan rugs and pillows, set up a portable table and decorated it with vases of flowers, a tea set and Moroccan lanterns. The surrounding dunes were continually changing shape because of the near-constant wind. A sign inside the park reads: “When you left your car in the parking lot, you left stability behind.”

abstract: The pandemic gave us a newfound appreciation for educators. Now let’s compensate them accordingly.
lead_paragraph: During the Covid-19 pandemic, debates over school closures and student safety grew in an understandable way. But this back and forth left no oxygen for robust conversation about lagging salaries for K-12 educators — an issue that was finally getting the attention it deserved before Covid hit. But now that each week brings more vaccine jabs and more news of school districts fully reopening in the fall, it’s time for this issue to get back in the spotlight.

By contrast, Brian Geldin, is more of an introvert. “I have always been more of a tight-lipped, dry sense of humor kind of guy,” he said.

headline: The U.S. May Never Hit the Herd Immunity Threshold. That’s OK.
abstract: Americans may not need to achieve that goal in order to escape the Covid-19 pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Half of Americans have now received at least one dose of a Covid-19 vaccine, and with children ages 12 to 15 now eligible for immunizations, the United States appears to be getting the coronavirus pandemic under control. But despite the tremendous progress, it’s still not clear that the nation will ever truly reach the herd immunity threshold — the point at which enough people in a population are immune to a pathogen to limit its spread.

The domino effect of household transmission was like a spark that set our house on fire. It was one of the most frightening experiences of my life — and I am an infectious disease epidemiologist who responded to the Ebola outbreak in 2014.

headline: The Forgotten Queer Legacy of Billy West and Zuni Café
keywords: ['Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Restaurants', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Cooking and Cookbooks']
abstract: The restaurant is a culinary landmark in San Francisco, but its history as a space for gay visibility is little known.
lead_paragraph: In 2013 Judy Rodgers, the 57-year-old chef of Zuni Café in San Francisco, yielded at last to the rare appendix cancer she’d struggled with for more than a year. The many published tributes to Ms. Rodgers celebrated the urgent beauty in her deceptively simple dishes: the way Zuni’s roast chicken, house-cured anchovies and Caesar salad were woven into memories of perfect meals.

keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Bases and Installations', 'Defense and Military Forces']

It was my first deployment to Afghanistan. I wanted to buy the new Weezer album (the “Red Album,” featuring “Pork and Beans”) and watch “Forgetting Sarah Marshall” when I got back.

headline: A Trump Case Awaits. Who Is the Best Prosecutor for the Job?

lead_paragraph: During its 20 year run, “Law & Order” cast five different actors in the role of Manhattan district attorney, a rate of turnover that feels like science fiction given that, in reality, four people have been elected to the office in 83 years. For the past 46 of them, the position, one of the most important prosecutorial posts in the country, has been held by two people, each an aristocrat born to a political dynasty: First, Robert M. Morgenthau, son of Henry Morgenthau Jr., who served as treasury secretary under two presidents (and who was himself the son of the United States ambassador to the Ottoman Empire); and since 2010, Cy Vance, son of the former secretary of state for whom he is named.

You are the matriarch of the family now, and I’m giving this to you.”

headline: Chelsea Wins the Champions League, Its Chaos Conquering City’s Plan
abstract: Chelsea won the Champions League for the second time, defeating Manchester City in a battle for control of European soccer’s biggest prize.

They stood, as if frozen in place, as Chelsea’s players heaved the prize City craves more than any other into the air. They could not go. To go, after all, would be to accept that it was real, that it was over.

Merrill Stubing on “The Love Boat” — died on Saturday at his home in Palm Desert, Calif. He was 90.

lead_paragraph: The Notorious B.I.G., stoic and resplendent in front of the twin towers. Tupac Shakur, eyes closed and arms in the air, tendrils of smoke wafting up from his lips. Eazy-E, perched atop his lowrider, using it as a throne. Mobb Deep, huddled with friends on the rooftop of a Queensbridge housing project. Nas, reflective in his childhood bedroom. lead_paragraph: LONDON — Only a week ago, Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain and his fiancée, Carrie Symonds, sent friends save-the-date cards for a wedding in July 2022, according to several British newspapers. But on Saturday, Mr. Johnson and Ms. Symonds were married in a stealth ceremony at Westminster Cathedral in London.

The best part is you don’t need any special or fancy equipment, you don’t need to remember a charger, you just need your eyes and the power of observation.

abstract: Using maps, newspaper clippings, testimonies and more, a team of graphics editors created an interactive 3-D portrait of the community that was burned down in 1921.

headline: The Beautiful, Flawed Fiction of ‘Asian American’
abstract: Against the racist and sexist fiction of the “Oriental,” we built the anti-racist, anti-sexist fiction of the Asian American.
lead_paragraph: One is not born an Asian American. It’s an identity that is inherently political, and must be chosen. Before college, I had never even heard of the term, but I vividly remember the moment that I became Asian American.

headline: How Young G.O.P. Leaders Sold Out Their Generation
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2020', 'Youth', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Millennial Generation', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Generation Z', 'Global Warming']
abstract: Elise Stefanik’s rise — and the fall of several young House colleagues — is an omen for a party struggling to reach a 21st-century electorate.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, a shiny new trio of young conservatives — Ryan Costello, Carlos Curbelo and Elise Stefanik — wanted to help build a modern, millennial Republican Party. The 30-somethings, all sworn into Congress in 2015, understood that millennials often agreed on many of the nation’s core problems, and believed it was up to them to offer conservative solutions. They were out to create a new G.O.P. for the 21st century.

headline: I Wrote James Bond Movies. The Amazon-MGM Deal Gives Me Chills.
abstract: The character endures  because he is  protected by people who love him.
lead_paragraph: So, Amazon now owns 50 percent of 007.

headline: The Vogueing Protesters of Bogotá
abstract: “We were scared, but the people and the love from the public was our gasoline to go up there and confront the police,” said one.
lead_paragraph: For weeks, thousands of people have crowded the streets of Colombia, protesting inequality, rising poverty and police violence. President Iván Duque has deployed the country’s military and police forces, and more than 40 people have died.

headline: What I’ve Learned Teaching the Tulsa Race Massacre for Two Decades
keywords: ['Tulsa Race Riot (1921)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Black People', 'Blacks', 'History (Academic Subject)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The project of healing history’s wounds is difficult but necessary work.
lead_paragraph: About a decade ago, when a class of third-, fourth- and fifth-grade students at Mayo Demonstration School in Tulsa, Okla., were studying the city’s history, their team of teachers gave them a special assignment: build a scale model of its once segregated Black business district, Greenwood, which was known as Black Wall Street.

headline: Shopping for Fans
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Furniture', 'Design', 'Fans (Airflow)', 'Content Type: Service']
abstract: Because it’s getting hot out there.
lead_paragraph: When the temperature rises, it’s time to break out the floor, table and desk fans, especially if you don’t have central air-conditioning.

headline: As Harvard Case Looms at Supreme Court, Study Tests Value of Diversity
abstract: After prestigious law reviews adopted diversity policies for choosing student editors, researchers found, the articles they published were cited more often.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court is set to consider next week whether to hear a challenge to Harvard’s race-conscious admissions program. If the justices take the case — a reasonably safe bet — affirmative action in higher education, which has survived several close calls at the court, will again be in peril.

headline: Clinics Close, but Abortion Continues
keywords: ['Abortion', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Abortion Drugs', 'Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Women and Girls', 'Mifeprex (RU-486)']
abstract: Even as abortion is restricted, telemedicine allows some women to end unwanted pregnancies using legal medications.
lead_paragraph: Abortion is once again a prominent source of controversy, restrictive legislation and, for many, great distress. A little background may help put this in perspective.

headline: With a Chinese American Gunslinger, He’s Challenging the Whiteness of Westerns
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Chinese-Americans', 'Writing and Writers', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Railroads', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Asian-Americans']
abstract: Tom Lin is making his debut with “The Thousand Crimes of Ming Tsu,” a novel that has drawn comparisons to Cormac McCarthy and “True Grit.”
lead_paragraph: Ming Tsu, the bloodthirsty outlaw in Tom Lin’s surreal new Western, has a lethal superpower: His victims, blinded by their own bias, don’t realize he’s a threat until it’s too late.

headline: For 40 Years, He Climbed Ev’ry Mountain for Rodgers & Hammerstein
keywords: ['Theater', 'Music', 'Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Ted Chapin steps down as the head of the organization that makes sure you revisit “Oklahoma!” and keep hearing “The Sound of Music.”
lead_paragraph: In 1981, two years after the death of Richard Rodgers and 21 years after the death of Oscar Hammerstein II, Ted Chapin got a call from Rodgers’s daughter Mary, asking if he’d like to run the Rodgers & Hammerstein office.

headline: On the Covid Front Lines, When Not Getting Belly Rubs
abstract: In Thailand and around the world, dogs are being trained to sniff out the coronavirus in people. So far, the results have been impressive.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Bobby was a good boy. So was Bravo.

headline: A New Era Dawns for Harley-Davidson
abstract: The feature-stuffed Pan America is a stark diversion for a company long associated with bulky, expensive cruisers. Early impressions suggest a potential blockbuster.
lead_paragraph: Recent years have not been kind to Harley-Davidson. Its sales have sagged, its core customers have aged, and its push toward the electric future, while newly serious, has underwhelmed so far.

headline: Why the Pandemic Was a Breakout Moment for the Cannabis Industry
abstract: For many Americans, having enough marijuana was as essential as stocking up on toilet paper. And suppliers found a way to get it to them.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Owning the Future, a series on how small businesses across the country have been affected by the pandemic.

headline: Pools, From Above
abstract: On Memorial Day, just in time for summer’s unofficial start, allow yourself a moment of relaxation with these soothing aerial photos of cool, enticing waters.
lead_paragraph: A pool can be soothing long before you wade into its waters. Even viewed from a distance, pools can evoke a sense of stillness, a sense of calm.

headline: A Siege, a Supply Run and a Descent Into a Decade-Old Battle
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )']
abstract: ‘Do you have body armor?’ the Afghan pilot asked us as we prepared for a trip to outposts surrounded by the Taliban.
lead_paragraph: MARJA, Afghanistan — The Afghan pilots discussed the approach into the small cluster of forward operating bases in Afghanistan’s south over tea and a lunch of rice pulao, much like surgeons discussing their next procedure. It would be quick, no more than 40 seconds on the ground, both helicopters landing at the same time, unloading the supplies before yanking up fast to get away from the easily targeted landing zones.

headline: Here’s the Arctic Station That Keeps Satellites Connected
abstract: The world’s northernmost tracking base, on a Norwegian island, plays a crucial role in supporting research on climate change.
lead_paragraph: Arrayed across a plateau on an island in the high Norwegian Arctic, the 100 geodesic domes of the Svalbard Satellite Station look like abstract mushrooms sprouting from the snowy landscape.

headline: From One Child to Three: How China’s Family Planning Policies Have Evolved
keywords: ['Population', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Politics and Government', 'Birth Rates']
abstract: For decades, couples were generally limited to one child to slow population growth. With a potential demographic crisis looming, the government now wants them to have more.
lead_paragraph: China on Monday increased the number of children married couples are legally permitted to have, to three from two, in an effort to stave off a looming crisis as the birthrate in the world’s most populous country steadily falls.

headline: Turkey Claims to Have ‘Captured’ Cleric’s Relative in Kenya
keywords: ['Politics and Government', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat"]
abstract: The removal of a Turkish citizen from his home in Kenya is part of the crackdown by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan on those he sees as connected to a failed 2016 coup.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey’s intelligence service claims it has “captured” a Turkish citizen related to a cleric they say orchestrated a failed coup, and taken him from his home in Kenya to Turkey, the state-run Anadolu news agency reported Monday.

headline: O.E.C.D. Raises Global Growth Forecast Sharply, Citing Vaccines
keywords: ['Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The world economy is expected to expand by 5.8 percent this year, but success depends on beating down variants of the virus, the group said.
lead_paragraph: The global economy is expected to recover from the coronavirus pandemic faster than expected this year, as vaccinations in advanced economies and an enormous fiscal stimulus package in the United States unleash pent-up business activity and job creation, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said on Monday.

lead_paragraph: People have been metal detecting since 1881, when Alexander Graham Bell invented a device to find the bullet lodged in President James Garfield.

abstract: A 1925 Spanish-style house in Los Angeles, an 1890 Victorian in San Luis Obispo and a brand-new home in Encinitas.

abstract: A 1925 Spanish-style house in Los Angeles, an 1890 Victorian in San Luis Obispo and a brand-new contemporary home in Cardiff-by-the-Sea.
lead_paragraph: Set along a winding street in the Hollywood Hills, just above the nightlife of the Sunset Strip, this property manages to be private and serene in a bustling area, with plenty of outdoor space and views of greenery from almost every room. The heart of Beverly Hills and the Cedars-Sinai medical complex are about 10 minutes away by car; the Miracle Mile business district and the backlots of Studio City are a 20-minute drive.

headline: Looking Beyond the Ayatollah to the Treasures of Iran
abstract: The organizers of a major London exhibition wanted to put politics aside and showcase the country’s rich 5,000-year-old culture. But politics kept getting in the way.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The board game is roughly 4,500 years old. Shaped like a bird of prey, it has holes running down its wings and chest, where the pieces were once positioned. It’s one of a few dozen ancient objects that were set to travel from the National Museum of Iran for a spectacular exhibition at the Victoria & Albert Museum here. But they never came.

headline: Two New Laws Restrict Police Use of DNA Search Method
keywords: ['Forensic Science', 'Genealogy', 'Law and Legislation', 'your-feed-science', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Privacy', 'Genetics and Heredity']
abstract: Maryland and Montana have passed the nation’s first laws limiting forensic genealogy, the method that found the Golden State Killer.
lead_paragraph: New laws in Maryland and Montana are the first in the nation to restrict law enforcement’s use of genetic genealogy, the DNA matching technique that in 2018 identified the Golden State Killer, in an effort to ensure the genetic privacy of the accused and their relatives.

headline: Retired F.B.I. Agent Is Accused of Swindling Texas Woman Out of $800,000
abstract: The former agent told the woman she was on “secret probation” over drug crimes and at one point proposed marriage, federal prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A retired F.B.I. agent in Texas has been indicted on fraud charges and accused of conning a woman out of $800,000 by convincing her that she was on “secret probation” for drug crimes and needed to pay him and an accomplice for their work to “mentor” and “supervise” her, federal prosecutors said on Friday.

headline: Raimund Hoghe, Choreographer of Strength and Frailty, Dies at 72
abstract: Born with a spinal deformity, he doubted he could ever dance, but he was able to incorporate his physical handicaps into his performances.
lead_paragraph: Raimund Hoghe, the German performer and choreographer who worked as a dramaturge for the choreographer Pina Bausch before creating dance-theater pieces that made as their subject his own body’s limitations, died on May 14 at his home in Düsseldorf. He was 72.

headline: Chris Paul Won’t Be Kept Off the Court
abstract: His coach had been inclined to sideline him as he deals with a shoulder injury. But he talked his way into the lineup and helped Phoenix tie its series with the Lakers.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A little over a week ago, Chris Paul christened the Phoenix Suns’ first trip to the postseason since the 2009-10 season with a bit of style. Paul, who is 6 feet tall, does not dunk often, but he rose to the occasion during warm-ups for the opening game of the Suns’ first-round series with the Lakers, leaping for an alley-oop as his teammates — and thousands of fans in Phoenix — celebrated in unison. It felt like a party. The city brimmed with hope.

headline: For China’s Single Mothers, a Road to Recognition Paved With False Starts
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Single Persons', "Women's Rights", 'Parenting', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Unmarried mothers are often denied government benefits. A debate over the policy is being propelled by a declining birthrate and a new generation of independent Chinese women.
lead_paragraph: For a few glorious weeks, Zou Xiaoqi, a single mother in Shanghai, felt accepted by her government.

headline: Olivia Rodrigo’s ‘Sour’ Scores the Biggest Debut of the Year
abstract: The teen pop phenomenon’s first album opened with the equivalent of 295,000 sales in the United States, including the second-best streaming total of 2021 so far.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, the name Olivia Rodrigo barely registered in the music business. Back then, she was a teenage Disney actress who had moderate success contributing to the soundtrack of her show “High School Musical: The Musical: The Series.”

headline: Recipes for Memorial Day
abstract: It’s a solemn day for many. Take a moment, before you cook, to honor its purpose and import.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Here’s Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. on Memorial Day, from an 1884 address he gave in Keene, N.H., “in the full tide of spring, at the height of the symphony of flowers and love and life.” It’s worth recalling before anyone heads out into a yard or park today to grill with friends, a reminder of the purpose and import of the day.

keywords: ['Content Type: Personal Profile', 'Archaeology and Anthropology', 'Roman Civilization', "Women's Rights", 'Slavery (Historical)']
abstract: “What the Romans are teaching is always at that meta level of what it might be like to take a view different from your own.”
lead_paragraph: “What the Romans are teaching is always at that meta level of what it might be like to take a view different from your own.”

headline: Can I Ask Co-Workers if They’ve Had the Covid Vaccine?
keywords: ['Coronavirus Risks and Safety Concerns', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Coronavirus (2019-nCoV)', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Ethics (Personal)']
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on why asking about vaccine status isn’t a question of etiquette but of public health.
lead_paragraph: My employer, a large university, recently instructed us in an email titled “Vaccine Etiquette” not to ask fellow employees if they are vaccinated. I feel I have an interest in knowing this information for two reasons: First, the C.D.C. offers different guidelines for the vaccinated and unvaccinated. So I need this information to know which guidelines to follow. Second, if we are engaging in behavior that creates risk (e.g., breathing in an enclosed space), I have an interest in knowing what the risks are, in the same way that before having sex with someone I have a cognizable interest in knowing their S.T.D. status. Most people would not consider asking a person their S.T.D. status rude when both parties are engaging in potentially risky behavior. Why is this different?

headline: More Than a Third of Heat Deaths Are Tied to Climate Change, Study Says
abstract: Sweeping new research found that heat-related deaths in warm seasons were boosted by climate change by an average of 37 percent.
lead_paragraph: More than a third of heat-related deaths in many parts of the world can be attributed to the extra warming associated with climate change, according to a new study that makes a case for taking strong action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in order to protect public health.

headline: The Pandemic in the U.S. Has Vastly Improved. For These Families, the Worst Has Just Begun.
abstract: Families losing a loved one to the coronavirus now described a surreal, lonely kind of grief, as the threat from the pandemic lessens in the United States.
lead_paragraph: After more than a year of pandemic restrictions, many Americans are leaving their masks behind, making summer travel plans and joyously reuniting with family and friends. As more are vaccinated and new infections plummet, there is a sense that the worst of the pandemic is over in the United States.

headline: Why One American Basketball Team Won’t Be at the Summer Olympics
abstract: The U.S. invented basketball but does not dominate one form, three-on-three, when it comes to Olympics qualifying. So, go … Latvia?
lead_paragraph: When three-on-three basketball has its Olympics debut in Tokyo this summer, Latvia will be there. So will Poland. But a men’s team from the United States, birthplace of basketball and winner of 15 of 19 men’s gold medals in the traditional five-on-five game, will not.

headline: How a Police Chief in Wyoming’s Ranchlands Lost Her War on Drugs
abstract: A campaign over meth, money and accountability cost law enforcement officers in Guernsey, Wyo., their jobs. Now their lawsuits are prying open the town’s secrets.
lead_paragraph: GUERNSEY, Wyo. — It was a few days before New Year’s Eve 2019, and Terri VanDam, the chief of Guernsey, Wyo.’s three-person Police Department, had run out of options.

headline: Britain Accelerates Relocation of Afghan Interpreters to U.K.
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Translation and Interpreters', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Britain will expedite the relocation of Afghan staff, largely interpreters, who worked for the country’s armed forces and are at increasing risk ahead of the withdrawal of U.S. and NATO troops.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain will expedite the relocation of Afghan staff and their families who worked for the British government in Afghanistan, largely as interpreters, the Ministry of Defense said on Monday, acknowledging they had an obligation to protect local employees from Taliban threats as Western troops withdraw from the country.

headline: ‘We’re Free Because They Were Brave’
abstract: Memorial Day had a special significance a year after many ceremonies honoring the nation’s fallen were canceled because of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: A day set aside to honor the sacrifices of the nation’s veterans, Memorial Day 2021 was especially poignant a year after many memorial ceremonies — and many family trips and barbecues — were curtailed because of the coronavirus pandemic. Parades that had been canceled in 2020 were back in 2021. Services held online last year resumed in person this year. Holiday traffic returned, as did beach outings — at least in parts of the country not cursed with cold, rainy weather.

headline: Can a New ‘Change Government’ Change Israel?
abstract: The main players in the latest twist in Israeli politics have very different agendas, but one common goal: unseating Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Naftali Bennett, who leads a small right-wing party, and Yair Lapid, the centrist leader of the Israeli opposition, have joined forces to try to form a diverse coalition that would unseat Benjamin Netanyahu, Israel’s longest-serving prime minister.

headline: Delhi Reopens a Crack Amid Gloomy Economic Forecast for India
abstract: The Indian capital lifted restrictions on manufacturing and construction, critical drivers of an economy that has been battered by the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Indian capital, which just weeks ago suffered the devastating force of the coronavirus, with tens of thousands of new infections daily and funeral pyres that burned day and night, is taking its first steps back toward normalcy.

headline: Naomi Osaka Quits the French Open
abstract: The four-time Grand Slam winner was fined after refusing to appear at a news conference. She wrote on Instagram that she had suffered from bouts of depression since 2018.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Naomi Osaka dropped out of the French Open one day after officials threatened to expel her from the season’s second Grand Slam tournament if she continued to refuse to attend news conferences after her matches.

headline: Lines Never Felt So Good: Crowds Herald New York’s Reopening
abstract: Museums broke attendance records, movie theaters sold out and jazz fans packed clubs on a rainy Memorial Day weekend that felt far removed from the prior year’s pandemic traumas.
lead_paragraph: The line outside the Metropolitan Museum of Art trailed out the door, down the rain-swept stairs, around the trees and past the fountain and the hot-dog stands on Fifth Avenue as visitors waited under dripping umbrellas. They were among more than 10,000 people who had the same idea for how to fill a rainy Sunday in New York City, turning the holiday weekend into the museum’s busiest since the start of the pandemic.

headline: How the ‘Wandering Meatloaf’ Got Its Rock-Hard Teeth
abstract: The dentition of the gumboot chiton, a lumbering mollusk, contains a super-hard mineral never before seen in a living animal.
lead_paragraph: The gumboot chiton is not a glamorous creature. The large, lumpy mollusk creeps along the waters of the Pacific coast, pulling its reddish-brown body up and down the shoreline. It is sometimes known, not unreasonably, as “the wandering meatloaf.” But the chiton’s unassuming body hides an array of tiny but formidable teeth. These teeth, which the creature uses to scrape algae from rocks, are among the hardest materials known to exist in a living organism.
